docs.title: Data Query Language (DQL) – Part 4: Subqueries & CTE (WITH)
docs.text: This part dives into Subqueries and CTEs (Common Table Expressions) with 6 core examples and 3 complex cases. Each example shows input tables, the SQL query, and the expected output.

docs.title: Employees
docs.text: EmpID Name DeptID Salary ManagerID 101 Amit Sharma 1 50000 nan 102 Riya Mehta 2 70000 101 103 Arjun Rao 3 55000 101 104 Neha Singh 2 80000 102 105 Rohit Verma 1 48000 101 106 Priya Nair 2 65000 102

docs.title: Departments
docs.text: DeptID DeptName 1 HR 2 IT 3 Finance 4 Marketing

docs.title: OrderItems
docs.text: OrderID Product Qty UnitPrice 1 Laptop 1 60000 1 Mouse 2 1000 2 Tablet 3 15000 3 Laptop 1 60000 3 Phone 2 20000 4 Phone 1 20000 5 Laptop 1 60000 6 Mouse 5 1000

docs.title: 1) Scalar Subquery – Employees earning above company average
docs.text:
SELECT EmpID, Name, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE Salary > (SELECT AVG(Salary) FROM Employees)
ORDER BY Salary DESC;

Output | EmpID | Name | Salary | |--------:|:-----------|---------:| | 104 | Neha Singh | 80000 | | 102 | Riya Mehta | 70000 | | 106 | Priya Nair | 65000 |

docs.title: 2) IN Subquery – Employees in departments having more than 1 employee
docs.text:
SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, e.DeptID, d.DeptName
FROM Employees e
JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
WHERE e.DeptID IN (
  SELECT DeptID
  FROM Employees
  GROUP BY DeptID
  HAVING COUNT(*) > 1
)
ORDER BY e.DeptID, e.Name;

Output | EmpID | Name | DeptID | DeptName | |--------:|:------------|---------:|:-----------| | 101 | Amit Sharma | 1 | HR | | 105 | Rohit Verma | 1 | HR | | 104 | Neha Singh | 2 | IT | | 106 | Priya Nair | 2 | IT | | 102 | Riya Mehta | 2 | IT |

docs.title: 3) EXISTS (Correlated) – Employees who have placed at least one order
docs.text:
SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name
FROM Employees e
WHERE EXISTS (
  SELECT 1
  FROM Orders o
  WHERE o.EmpID = e.EmpID
)
ORDER BY e.EmpID;

Output | EmpID | Name | |--------:|:-----------| | 102 | Riya Mehta | | 103 | Arjun Rao | | 104 | Neha Singh | | 106 | Priya Nair |

docs.title: 4) NOT EXISTS – Departments with no employees
docs.text:
SELECT d.DeptID, d.DeptName
FROM Departments d
WHERE NOT EXISTS (
  SELECT 1
  FROM Employees e
  WHERE e.DeptID = d.DeptID
)
ORDER BY d.DeptID;

Output | DeptID | DeptName | |---------:|:-----------| | 4 | Marketing |

docs.title: 5) Subquery in FROM (Derived Table) – Revenue by product
docs.text:
SELECT t.Product, t.TotalRevenue
FROM (
  SELECT oi.Product,
         SUM(oi.Qty * oi.UnitPrice) AS TotalRevenue
  FROM OrderItems oi
  GROUP BY oi.Product
) AS t
ORDER BY t.TotalRevenue DESC;

Output | Product | TotalRevenue | |:----------|---------------:| | Laptop | 180000 | | Phone | 60000 | | Tablet | 45000 | | Mouse | 7000 |

docs.title: 6) ANY/ALL – Salary greater than ALL salaries in HR
docs.text:
SELECT Name, Salary
FROM Employees
WHERE Salary > ALL (
  SELECT Salary FROM Employees WHERE DeptID = 1
)
ORDER BY Salary DESC;

Output | Name | Salary | |:-----------|---------:| | Neha Singh | 80000 | | Riya Mehta | 70000 | | Priya Nair | 65000 | | Arjun Rao | 55000 |

docs.title: 7) CTE – Revenue per employee
docs.text:
WITH OrderTotals AS (
  SELECT oi.OrderID, SUM(oi.Qty * oi.UnitPrice) AS OrderTotal
  FROM OrderItems oi
  GROUP BY oi.OrderID
)
SELECT e.Name, SUM(ot.OrderTotal) AS Revenue
FROM Orders o
JOIN OrderTotals ot ON o.OrderID = ot.OrderID
JOIN Employees e ON o.EmpID = e.EmpID
GROUP BY e.Name
ORDER BY Revenue DESC;

Output | Name | Revenue | |:-----------|----------:| | Riya Mehta | 162000 | | Arjun Rao | 60000 | | Neha Singh | 45000 | | Priya Nair | 25000 |

docs.title: 8) Multiple CTEs – Per-customer orders & revenue
docs.text:
WITH OrderTotals AS (
  SELECT oi.OrderID, SUM(oi.Qty * oi.UnitPrice) AS OrderTotal
  FROM OrderItems oi
  GROUP BY oi.OrderID
),
CustomerOrders AS (
  SELECT o.Customer, o.OrderID, ot.OrderTotal
  FROM Orders o
  JOIN OrderTotals ot ON o.OrderID = ot.OrderID
)
SELECT Customer,
       COUNT(DISTINCT OrderID) AS Orders,
       SUM(OrderTotal)         AS Revenue
FROM CustomerOrders
GROUP BY Customer
ORDER BY Revenue DESC;

Output | Customer | Orders | Revenue | |:-----------|---------:|----------:| | Crown | 1 | 100000 | | Acme | 3 | 87000 | | Delta | 1 | 60000 | | Bolt | 1 | 45000 |

docs.title: 9) Recursive CTE – Organization levels
docs.text:
WITH RECURSIVE Org AS (
  SELECT EmpID, Name, ManagerID, 0 AS Level
  FROM Employees
  WHERE ManagerID IS NULL
  UNION ALL
  SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, e.ManagerID, o.Level + 1
  FROM Employees e
  JOIN Org o ON e.ManagerID = o.EmpID
)
SELECT EmpID, Name, Level
FROM Org
ORDER BY Level, EmpID;

Output | EmpID | Name | Level | |--------:|:------------|--------:| | 101 | Amit Sharma | 0 | | 102 | Riya Mehta | 1 | | 103 | Arjun Rao | 1 | | 105 | Rohit Verma | 1 | | 104 | Neha Singh | 2 | | 106 | Priya Nair | 2 |

docs.title: Complex A) Top 2 earners per department (CTE + window function)
docs.text:
WITH Ranked AS (
  SELECT d.DeptName, e.Name, e.Salary,
         ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY e.DeptID ORDER BY e.Salary DESC) AS rn
  FROM Employees e
  LEFT JOIN Departments d ON e.DeptID = d.DeptID
)
SELECT DeptName, Name, Salary, rn AS Rank
FROM Ranked
WHERE rn <= 2
ORDER BY DeptName, Rank, Name;

Output | DeptName | Name | Salary | Rank | |:-----------|:------------|---------:|-------:| | Finance | Arjun Rao | 55000 | 1 | | HR | Amit Sharma | 50000 | 1 | | HR | Rohit Verma | 48000 | 2 | | IT | Neha Singh | 80000 | 1 | | IT | Riya Mehta | 70000 | 2 |

docs.title: Complex B) Highest revenue product per customer (CTE + ranking)
docs.text:
WITH CustProd AS (
  SELECT o.Customer, oi.Product,
         SUM(oi.Qty * oi.UnitPrice) AS Revenue
  FROM Orders o
  JOIN OrderItems oi ON o.OrderID = oi.OrderID
  GROUP BY o.Customer, oi.Product
),
Ranked AS (
  SELECT Customer, Product, Revenue,
         ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY Customer ORDER BY Revenue DESC) AS rk
  FROM CustProd
)
SELECT Customer, Product, Revenue
FROM Ranked
WHERE rk = 1
ORDER BY Customer;

Output | Customer | Product | Revenue | |:-----------|:----------|----------:| | Acme | Laptop | 60000 | | Bolt | Tablet | 45000 | | Crown | Laptop | 60000 | | Delta | Laptop | 60000 |

docs.title: Complex C) Manager → Employee pairs (recursive CTE for relationships)
docs.text:
WITH RECURSIVE Tree AS (
  SELECT EmpID, Name, ManagerID, CAST(Name AS VARCHAR(200)) AS Path
  FROM Employees
  WHERE ManagerID IS NULL
  UNION ALL
  SELECT e.EmpID, e.Name, e.ManagerID, CAST(t.Path || ' > ' || e.Name AS VARCHAR(200))
  FROM Employees e
  JOIN Tree t ON e.ManagerID = t.EmpID
)
SELECT * FROM Tree ORDER BY Path;

Output | Manager | Employee | |:------------|:------------| | Amit Sharma | Arjun Rao | | Amit Sharma | Riya Mehta | | Amit Sharma | Rohit Verma | | Riya Mehta | Neha Singh | | Riya Mehta | Priya Nair |

✅ In this part, you learned: - Scalar, IN, EXISTS/NOT EXISTS, ANY/ALL subqueries - Derived tables (subquery in FROM) - CTEs (single, multiple) and recursive CTEs for hierarchies - Complex patterns using window functions + CTEs

docs.title: 🔹 What is TCL?
docs.text: TCL commands manage transactions in the database. They ensure data integrity and control how changes are saved or undone.

docs.title: 1. COMMIT
docs.text:
• Saves changes permanently.
COMMIT;

docs.title: 2. ROLLBACK
docs.text:
• Undo changes since last commit.
ROLLBACK;

docs.title: 3. SAVEPOINT
docs.text:
• Creates a point to rollback partially.
SAVEPOINT sp1;
ROLLBACK TO sp1;

docs.title: 4. SET TRANSACTION
docs.text:
• Sets transaction properties like isolation level.
SET TRANSACTION READ ONLY;

docs.title: ✅ Pros
docs.text:
1. Transaction Safety → Prevents accidental data loss.
  2. Consistency → Maintains ACID properties.
  3. Flexibility → Can rollback fully or partially.
  4. Control → Developers control when to save changes.

docs.title: ❌ Cons
docs.text:
1. Complexity → Misuse can cause locks.
  2. Performance → Frequent rollbacks may reduce speed.
  3. Overhead → Managing multiple savepoints may be costly.
  4. Limited Scope → Works only with DML changes.

docs.title: ✅ Summary Table
docs.text: Command Purpose Rollback Possible Example Usage COMMIT Save all changes permanently ❌ No End transaction ROLLBACK Undo changes ✅ Yes Revert mistaken updates SAVEPOINT Partial rollback ✅ Yes Rollback to checkpoint SET TRANSACTION Define transaction behavior N/A Read-only transaction

docs.title: 📊 TCL Commands – Feature Comparison
docs.text: Command Rollback Data Loss Structure Change Typical Use Case COMMIT ❌ No ❌ No ❌ No Save all operations ROLLBACK ✅ Yes ❌ No ❌ No Undo operations SAVEPOINT ✅ Yes ❌ No ❌ No Rollback to savepoint SET TRANSACTION N/A ❌ No ❌ No Define isolation level

docs.title: SQL Practice: Advanced / Complex Joins for ETL Testing
docs.text:
This file contains 10 SQL practice problems covering:

  • Cross Join (Cartesian product)
  • Self-join with multiple conditions
  • Join with subqueries
  • Join multiple tables (3–4 tables)

Each question includes:

  • Input Table(s)
  • Question
  • SQL Query
  • Explanation
  • Output Table

docs.title: Q1: Generate all combinations of employees and projects
docs.text:
Input Tables:

employees

emp_id name 1 Alice 2 Bob

projects

project_id project_name 101 Alpha 102 Beta

Query:

SELECT e.name, p.project_name
FROM employees e
CROSS JOIN projects p;

Explanation:

  • CROSS JOIN generates all possible combinations between two tables.
  • Useful in ETL testing when validating assignment of employees to all possible project slots.

Output:

name project_name Alice Alpha Alice Beta Bob Alpha Bob Beta

docs.title: Q2: Find employees with the same department
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name dept_id 1 Alice 10 2 Bob 10 3 Charlie 20 4 David 10

Query:

SELECT e1.name AS emp1, e2.name AS emp2, e1.dept_id
FROM employees e1
JOIN employees e2
  ON e1.dept_id = e2.dept_id
  AND e1.emp_id < e2.emp_id;

Explanation:

  • Self-join compares a table with itself.
  • e1.emp_id < e2.emp_id avoids duplicate pairs and self-pairing.
  • ETL use case: Validate peer relationships in the same group.

Output:

emp1 emp2 dept_id Alice Bob 10 Alice David 10 Bob David 10

docs.title: Q3: Employees reporting to same manager and in same department
docs.text:
Input Table: employees

emp_id name dept_id manager_id 1 Alice 10 100 2 Bob 10 100 3 Charlie 20 200 4 David 10 100

Query:

SELECT e1.name AS emp1, e2.name AS emp2, e1.dept_id, e1.manager_id
FROM employees e1
JOIN employees e2
  ON e1.dept_id = e2.dept_id
  AND e1.manager_id = e2.manager_id
  AND e1.emp_id < e2.emp_id;

Output:

emp1 emp2 dept_id manager_id Alice Bob 10 100 Alice David 10 100 Bob David 10 100

docs.title: Q4: Select employees working on highest salary projects
docs.text:
Input Tables:

employees

emp_id name project_id 1 Alice 101 2 Bob 102 3 Charlie 101

projects

project_id project_name budget 101 Alpha 5000 102 Beta 10000

Query:

SELECT e.name, p.project_name, p.budget
FROM employees e
JOIN projects p
  ON e.project_id = p.project_id
WHERE p.budget = (SELECT MAX(budget) FROM projects);

Explanation:

  • Subquery (SELECT MAX(budget) FROM projects) returns the largest project budget.
  • ETL use case: Validate transformation logic based on derived values from another table.

Output:

name project_name budget Bob Beta 10000

docs.title: Q5: Employee assignments with department and project names
docs.text:
Input Tables:

employees

emp_id name dept_id project_id 1 Alice 10 101 2 Bob 20 102

departments

dept_id dept_name 10 HR 20 IT

projects

project_id project_name 101 Alpha 102 Beta

Query:

SELECT e.name, d.dept_name, p.project_name
FROM employees e
JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id
JOIN projects p ON e.project_id = p.project_id;

Explanation:

  • Joining 3 tables to get full contextual information
  • ETL use case: Validate final transformed fact table combining multiple sources

Output:

name dept_name project_name Alice HR Alpha Bob IT Beta

docs.title: Q6: Employees in HR department working on budget > 5000 projects
docs.text:
Query:

SELECT e.name, d.dept_name, p.project_name, p.budget
FROM employees e
JOIN departments d ON e.dept_id = d.dept_id
JOIN projects p ON e.project_id = p.project_id
WHERE d.dept_name = 'HR' AND p.budget > 5000;

Output:

name dept_name project_name budget Alice HR Alpha 5000

docs.title: SQL Practice: Window / Analytic Functions with Explanations
docs.text:
This file contains 20 SQL practice problems covering:

  • ROW_NUMBER(), RANK(), DENSE_RANK()
  • NTILE(), LAG(), LEAD()
  • SUM()/AVG() OVER (PARTITION BY …)

Each question includes:

  • Input Table(s)
  • Question
  • SQL Query
  • Explanation
  • Output Table

docs.title: Q1: Assign row number per employee based on sale_date
docs.text:
SELECT sale_id, emp_id, sale_date,
       ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY emp_id ORDER BY sale_date) AS row_num
FROM sales;

Output:

sale_id emp_id sale_date row_num 1 101 2025-09-01 1 3 101 2025-09-02 2 6 101 2025-09-03 3 2 102 2025-09-01 1 5 102 2025-09-03 2 4 103 2025-09-02 1

docs.title: Q2: Rank sales per department
docs.text:
SELECT sale_id, emp_id, dept, sale_amount,
       RANK() OVER (PARTITION BY dept ORDER BY sale_amount DESC) AS dept_rank,
       DENSE_RANK() OVER (PARTITION BY dept ORDER BY sale_amount DESC) AS dense_rank
FROM sales;

Output:

sale_id emp_id dept sale_amount dept_rank dense_rank 3 101 IT 7000 1 1 1 101 IT 5000 2 2 4 103 IT 4000 3 3 5 102 HR 3500 1 1 2 102 HR 3000 2 2

docs.title: Q3: Divide IT department sales into 2 buckets
docs.text:
SELECT sale_id, emp_id, dept, sale_amount,
       NTILE(2) OVER (PARTITION BY dept ORDER BY sale_amount DESC) AS bucket
FROM sales
WHERE dept='IT';

Output:

sale_id emp_id dept sale_amount bucket 3 101 IT 7000 1 1 101 IT 5000 1 4 103 IT 4000 2 6 101 IT 6000 1

docs.title: Q4: Previous sale amount per employee
docs.text:
SELECT sale_id, emp_id, sale_amount,
       LAG(sale_amount,1) OVER (PARTITION BY emp_id ORDER BY sale_date) AS prev_sale
FROM sales;

Output:

sale_id emp_id sale_amount prev_sale 1 101 5000 NULL 3 101 7000 5000 6 101 6000 7000 2 102 3000 NULL 5 102 3500 3000 4 103 4000 NULL

docs.title: Q5: Next sale amount per employee
docs.text:
SELECT sale_id, emp_id, sale_amount,
       LEAD(sale_amount,1) OVER (PARTITION BY emp_id ORDER BY sale_date) AS next_sale
FROM sales;

Output:

sale_id emp_id sale_amount next_sale 1 101 5000 7000 3 101 7000 6000 6 101 6000 NULL 2 102 3000 3500 5 102 3500 NULL 4 103 4000 NULL

docs.title: Q6: Running total per employee
docs.text:
SELECT sale_id, emp_id, sale_amount,
       SUM(sale_amount) OVER (PARTITION BY emp_id ORDER BY sale_date) AS running_total
FROM sales;

Output:

sale_id emp_id sale_amount running_total 1 101 5000 5000 3 101 7000 12000 6 101 6000 18000 2 102 3000 3000 5 102 3500 6500 4 103 4000 4000

docs.title: Q7: Average sale per department
docs.text:
SELECT sale_id, emp_id, dept, sale_amount,
       AVG(sale_amount) OVER (PARTITION BY dept) AS avg_dept_sale
FROM sales;

Output:

sale_id emp_id dept sale_amount avg_dept_sale 1 101 IT 5000 5666.67 3 101 IT 7000 5666.67 4 103 IT 4000 5666.67 6 101 IT 6000 5666.67 2 102 HR 3000 3250 5 102 HR 3500 3250

docs.title: Explanation:
docs.text:
1. ROW_NUMBER(): Assigns unique numbers to rows within a partition.
  2. RANK()/DENSE_RANK(): Rank rows within a partition, with/without gaps.
  3. NTILE(): Divides rows into specified number of buckets.
  4. LAG()/LEAD(): Access previous/next row values.
  5. SUM()/AVG() OVER(PARTITION BY …): Cumulative or group-based aggregates without collapsing rows.

Use case in ETL Testing:

  • Detect duplicate records using ROW_NUMBER().
  • Validate ranking and top-N using RANK()/DENSE_RANK().
  • Check cumulative aggregates for correctness.
  • Compare current row with previous/next row for trends or anomalies.

docs.title: 9. Handling Dialogs, Alerts, and Prompts in Playwright (Java)
docs.text: Web applications often use dialogs like Alerts, Confirms, and Prompts for user interaction. Playwright provides APIs to handle these dialogs by listening to the dialog event.

docs.title: ✅ Types of JavaScript Dialogs
docs.text:
1. Alert
  2. Simple message with OK button.

  3. Example: alert("This is an alert!");

  4. Confirm

  5. Message with OK and Cancel buttons.

  6. Example: confirm("Are you sure?");

  7. Prompt

  8. Message with input field + OK/Cancel buttons.

  9. Example: prompt("Enter your name:");

  10. BeforeUnload

  11. Triggered when a user tries to close or reload a page.
  12. Example: window.onbeforeunload = () => true;

docs.title: 📌 Playwright Dialog API
docs.text:
• Event Listener for Dialog
page.onDialog(dialog -> {
    System.out.println("Dialog message: " + dialog.message());
    dialog.accept(); // or dialog.dismiss()
});
  • Dialog Methods
  • dialog.message() → Get text of the dialog.
  • dialog.type() → Returns type (alert, confirm, prompt, beforeunload).
  • dialog.accept([promptText]) → Accept the dialog (for prompt, send text).
  • dialog.dismiss() → Dismiss the dialog (Cancel).

docs.title: 📌 Example Code (Java + Playwright)
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;

public class DialogsExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();

            // Navigate to sample page with dialogs
            page.navigate("https://the-internet.herokuapp.com/javascript_alerts");

            // --- Handle Alert ---
            page.onceDialog(dialog -> {
                System.out.println("Alert Text: " + dialog.message());
                dialog.accept();
            });
            page.click("text=Click for JS Alert");

            // --- Handle Confirm (OK) ---
            page.onceDialog(dialog -> {
                System.out.println("Confirm Text: " + dialog.message());
                dialog.accept(); // choose OK
            });
            page.click("text=Click for JS Confirm");

            // --- Handle Confirm (Cancel) ---
            page.onceDialog(dialog -> {
                System.out.println("Confirm Text: " + dialog.message());
                dialog.dismiss(); // choose Cancel
            });
            page.click("text=Click for JS Confirm");

            // --- Handle Prompt with input ---
            page.onceDialog(dialog -> {
                System.out.println("Prompt Text: " + dialog.message());
                dialog.accept("PlaywrightUser"); // enter text
            });
            page.click("text=Click for JS Prompt");

            // --- Handle BeforeUnload ---
            page.onceDialog(dialog -> {
                System.out.println("BeforeUnload triggered");
                dialog.accept();
            });
            page.evaluate("() => window.onbeforeunload = () => true;");
            page.reload();

            browser.close();
        }
    }
}

docs.title: 🔑 Notes
docs.text:
• Use page.onDialog() for handling dialogs globally (persistent listener).
  • Use page.onceDialog() for handling a single occurrence.
  • For prompt dialogs, always provide text inside dialog.accept("yourText").
  • Playwright will auto-wait until dialog is shown before executing callback.
  • If dialogs are not handled → tests will fail (dialogs block execution).

✅ With these APIs, you can handle Alerts, Confirms, Prompts, and BeforeUnload dialogs in Playwright tests using Java.

docs.title: 7. Checkbox & Radio Button in Playwright (Java)
docs.text: Checkboxes and Radio buttons are common form elements used for binary selections (true/false, yes/no, option A/B). Playwright provides a clean API to handle these elements.

docs.title: 1. locator.check()
docs.text:
• Ensures the checkbox or radio button is checked.
  • If it’s already checked → does nothing.
  • If it’s disabled or hidden → Playwright waits until it’s actionable.

docs.title: 2. locator.uncheck()
docs.text:
• Ensures the checkbox is unchecked.
  • Applicable only to checkboxes (not radio buttons).
  • If already unchecked → does nothing.

docs.title: 3. locator.isChecked()
docs.text: • Returns a boolean (true/false) if the checkbox or radio button is selected.

docs.title: 📌 Example Code (Java + Playwright)
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;

public class CheckboxRadioExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();

            // Navigate to sample page
            page.navigate("https://the-internet.herokuapp.com/checkboxes");

            // ✅ Locate checkbox
            Locator checkbox1 = page.locator("//form[@id='checkboxes']/input[1]");

            // --- Check a checkbox ---
            checkbox1.check();
            System.out.println("Checkbox 1 checked: " + checkbox1.isChecked());

            // --- Uncheck a checkbox ---
            checkbox1.uncheck();
            System.out.println("Checkbox 1 checked after uncheck: " + checkbox1.isChecked());

            // ✅ Radio button example
            page.navigate("https://demoqa.com/radio-button");

            Locator yesRadio = page.locator("input[id='yesRadio']");

            // --- Select radio button ---
            yesRadio.check();
            System.out.println("Yes Radio selected: " + yesRadio.isChecked());

            browser.close();
        }
    }
}

docs.title: 🔑 Notes
docs.text:
• Radio buttons: You can only select one option in a group.
  • Checkboxes: Can select multiple options unless restricted by form logic.
  • Use .isChecked() to verify the state before performing an action if needed.
  • Playwright automatically waits for the element to be visible, enabled, and ready for action.

✅ With these methods, you can reliably handle checkboxes and radio buttons in Playwright tests using Java.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Classic <select> Dropdown
docs.text:
HTML Example:

<select id="country">
  <option value="IN">India</option>
  <option value="US">USA</option>
  <option value="UK">UK</option>
</select>

docs.title: a) Select by Value
docs.text:
page.locator("#country").selectOption("IN");  
// Select India by value

docs.title: b) Select by Label (Visible Text)
docs.text:
page.locator("#country").selectOption(new SelectOption().setLabel("USA"));  
// Select USA by visible text

docs.title: c) Select by Index
docs.text:
page.locator("#country").selectOption(new SelectOption().setIndex(2));  
// Select 3rd option (UK) – index starts from 0

docs.title: d) Select Multiple Values
docs.text:
page.locator("#country").selectOption(new String[]{"IN", "US"});  
// Select India and USA (multi-select dropdowns only)

docs.title: e) Iterate All Options & Get Count
docs.text:
Locator options = page.locator("#country option");
int count = options.count();
System.out.println("Total options in dropdown: " + count);

for (int i = 0; i < count; i++) {
    System.out.println(options.nth(i).innerText());
}
  • Explanation:
    • count() → total number of options.
    • .nth(i).innerText() → retrieves text of each option.

docs.title: f) Example Full Flow
docs.text:
// Select India by value
page.locator("#country").selectOption("IN");

// Select USA by label
page.locator("#country").selectOption(new SelectOption().setLabel("USA"));

// Select multiple (India & UK)
page.locator("#country").selectOption(new String[]{"IN", "UK"});

// Iterate and print all options
Locator options = page.locator("#country option");
for (int i = 0; i < options.count(); i++) {
    System.out.println(options.nth(i).innerText());
}

docs.title: 2️⃣ Auto-suggestion / Custom Dropdown
docs.text:
HTML Example:

<input id="searchCity" type="text" placeholder="Enter city" />
<ul id="cityList">
  <li>New York</li>
  <li>London</li>
  <li>Delhi</li>
</ul>

docs.title: a) Type to Filter Suggestions
docs.text: page.locator("#searchCity").fill("Del");

docs.title: b) Click on Desired Option
docs.text: page.locator("#cityList li", new Locator.LocatorOptions().setHasText("Delhi")).click();

docs.title: c) Full Auto-suggestion Flow
docs.text:
// Type in search box
page.locator("#searchCity").fill("Del");

// Wait for suggestion and click
page.locator("#cityList li", new Locator.LocatorOptions().setHasText("Delhi")).click();

docs.title: d) Iterate All Auto-suggestion Options & Get Count
docs.text:
Locator cities = page.locator("#cityList li");
int totalCities = cities.count();
System.out.println("Total suggestions: " + totalCities);

for (int i = 0; i < totalCities; i++) {
    System.out.println(cities.nth(i).innerText());
}
  • Retrieves all suggestions and their total count.

docs.title: e) Tips for Auto-suggestion Dropdowns
docs.text:
• Use fill() instead of type() if you want instant input.
  • Use .locator(...).filter(...).click() to select the correct option.
  • Playwright handles auto-waiting automatically.

docs.title: ✅ Summary
docs.text:
• Classic <select> dropdowns:
    • selectOption("value") → select by value.
    • selectOption(new SelectOption().setLabel("...")) → select by visible text.
    • selectOption(new SelectOption().setIndex(i)) → select by index.
    • selectOption(new String[]{...}) → select multiple values.
    • Iterate options with .count() & .nth().
  • Auto-suggestion / custom dropdowns:
    • Use fill() to type, then locate the suggestion and click().
    • Iterate options with .count() & .nth().
  • Pro tips:
    • Playwright auto-waits for dropdowns.
    • Prefer semantic locators (getByLabel, getByText) for stability.

docs.title: Java Playwright – Common Exceptions and How to Handle Them
docs.text: Playwright in Java provides powerful automation features, but you may encounter exceptions during execution. This guide lists the most common exceptions, their causes, and solutions with code snippets.

docs.title: 1. TimeoutError
docs.text:
Cause: - An action (like click, fill, waitForSelector) did not complete within the default timeout (usually 30 seconds). - Element is not visible, attached, or ready for interaction.

Solution: - Increase timeout using setTimeout() or pass custom timeout in action options. - Ensure element is visible before interacting.

Code Example:

page.click("button#submit", new Page.ClickOptions().setTimeout(10000)); // 10 sec timeout

// Or set default timeout for the page
page.setDefaultTimeout(15000);

docs.title: 2. PlaywrightException (Generic Exception)
docs.text:
Cause: - Incorrect selectors (e.g., wrong CSS/XPath). - Performing actions on detached or invalid elements.

Solution: - Always validate selectors with page.locator() or page.isVisible(). - Use waitForSelector() before performing action.

Code Example:

if (page.isVisible("input#username")) {
    page.fill("input#username", "sandesh");
} else {
    System.out.println("Element not found!");
}

docs.title: 3. ElementHandleException
docs.text:
Cause: - Attempting to interact with a Locator or ElementHandle that is no longer attached to the DOM. - Example: Page refreshed or element re-rendered.

Solution: - Re-locate the element before interaction. - Use locator API instead of elementHandle where possible (auto-handles re-attachment).

Code Example:

Locator loginBtn = page.locator("#login");
loginBtn.click(); // safer than elementHandle

// If using elementHandle
ElementHandle handle = page.querySelector("#login");
handle.click(); // might fail if DOM changes

docs.title: 4. DownloadFailureException
docs.text:
Cause: - Download interrupted, canceled, or file not generated. - Permissions issue writing file.

Solution: - Ensure waitForDownload() is used properly. - Use download.saveAs() to explicitly save file to desired location.

Code Example:

Download download = page.waitForDownload(() -> {
    page.click("a#downloadLink");
});

download.saveAs(Paths.get("C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Downloads\\file.txt"));

docs.title: 5. NavigationException
docs.text:
Cause: - Page fails to navigate to a URL (e.g., network issues, invalid URL). - Timeout while waiting for page load.

Solution: - Use page.navigate() with explicit timeout. - Add retries for flaky connections.

Code Example:

page.navigate("https://example.com", new Page.NavigateOptions().setTimeout(20000));

docs.title: 6. WebSocketException
docs.text:
Cause: - Playwright internally communicates with browser over WebSocket. - Exception occurs when connection is lost (browser crash, closed unexpectedly).

Solution: - Restart browser context/session. - Add retry logic in test framework.

Code Example:

try {
    page.navigate("https://example.com");
} catch (PlaywrightException e) {
    System.out.println("Browser disconnected. Restarting...");
    // re-launch browser
}

docs.title: 7. SelectorResolutionException
docs.text:
Cause: - Invalid selector syntax (CSS or XPath). - Element does not exist.

Solution: - Test selector validity in browser dev tools. - Use page.locator() instead of page.querySelector() for better debugging.

Code Example:

Locator button = page.locator("button:has-text('Login')");
button.click();

docs.title: 8. AssertionError
docs.text:
Cause: - Assertions fail due to unexpected values. - Example: Page title mismatch.

Solution: - Print actual vs expected values for debugging. - Use retries or waits if data loads asynchronously.

Code Example:

String title = page.title();
assert title.equals("Expected Title") : "Title mismatch! Actual: " + title;

docs.title: 9. FileAlreadyExistsException
docs.text:
Cause: - While saving downloads/screenshots, file already exists at the same path.

Solution: - Save with a unique name using timestamp or UUID.

Code Example:

String fileName = "screenshot_" + System.currentTimeMillis() + ".png";
page.screenshot(new Page.ScreenshotOptions().setPath(Paths.get(fileName)));

docs.title: 10. IllegalStateException (Playwright Context)
docs.text:
Cause: - Trying to use closed browser/page/context. - Example: Performing action after calling browser.close().

Solution: - Ensure context/page is open before using. - Wrap in try-catch for cleanup.

Code Example:

try {
    page.click("#btn");
} catch (IllegalStateException e) {
    System.out.println("Page is already closed.");
}

docs.title: 📌 Summary
docs.text:
Exception Cause Solution TimeoutError Action exceeds wait time Increase timeout, wait for selector PlaywrightException Generic errors Validate selectors, wait for elements ElementHandleException Detached elements Use locator API DownloadFailureException Download failed Use waitForDownload() NavigationException Navigation failed Add timeout/retry WebSocketException Browser connection lost Restart session SelectorResolutionException Invalid selector Validate selector syntax AssertionError Assertion failed Print debug info, add waits FileAlreadyExistsException File path already exists Save with unique names IllegalStateException Using closed context Check before use

✅ This document covers all major exceptions in Java Playwright, with their causes, solutions, and code snippets.

docs.title: Java Playwright – File Upload & Download Examples
docs.text: This guide explains how to handle File Upload and File Download in Java Playwright with code samples.

docs.title: 📌 File Upload Concept
docs.text:
• Playwright does not interact with the native OS file chooser.
  • Instead, we use setInputFiles() to programmatically set files into <input type="file"> elements.
  • Supports single and multiple files.

docs.title: ✅ Upload Single File
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;

public class FileUploadSingle {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();

            page.navigate("https://www.w3schools.com/howto/howto_html_file_upload_button.asp");

            // Upload a single file
            page.setInputFiles("input[type='file']", "C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Desktop\\test.txt");

            // Assertion (Check if file input has value)
            String fileName = page.inputValue("input[type='file']");
            assert fileName.contains("test.txt");

            System.out.println("✅ Single File uploaded successfully");
        }
    }
}

docs.title: ✅ Upload Multiple Files
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;

public class FileUploadMultiple {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();

            page.navigate("https://www.w3schools.com/howto/howto_html_file_upload_button.asp");

            // Upload multiple files
            page.setInputFiles("input[type='file']", new String[] {
                "C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Desktop\\test1.txt",
                "C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Desktop\\test2.txt"
            });

            // Assertion (Check both file names are uploaded)
            String fileNames = page.inputValue("input[type='file']");
            assert fileNames.contains("test1.txt") && fileNames.contains("test2.txt");

            System.out.println("✅ Multiple Files uploaded successfully");
        }
    }
}

docs.title: 📌 File Download Concept
docs.text:
• Use page.waitForDownload() to capture the Download object.
  • Save the downloaded file to a desired location using download.saveAs().

docs.title: ✅ File Download Example
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;
import java.nio.file.Paths;

public class FileDownloadExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();

            page.navigate("https://file-examples.com/index.php/sample-documents-download/");

            // Wait for download event
            Download download = page.waitForDownload(() -> {
                page.click("a[href*='sample.doc']"); // sample download link
            });

            // Save the file to desired location
            download.saveAs(Paths.get("C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Downloads\\sample.doc"));

            // Assertion (Check file is downloaded successfully)
            assert download.path() != null;

            System.out.println("✅ File downloaded to: " + download.path());
        }
    }
}

docs.title: 🔹 Handling Dynamic Filenames
docs.text:
If the downloaded file has a random or dynamic name, you can:

Download download = page.waitForDownload(() -> {
    page.click("a.download-link");
});

// Save with a custom name regardless of original name
download.saveAs(Paths.get("C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Downloads\\myFile.docx"));

docs.title: 📌 Key Notes
docs.text:
• setInputFiles() works only on <input type="file"> elements.
  • Always use waitForDownload() to ensure the file is completely downloaded before accessing it.
  • You can add assertions to verify file name, existence, or size.

✅ This covers Single File Upload, Multiple File Upload with Assertions, and File Download Handling in Java Playwright.

docs.title: 11. Windows & Tabs Handling in Playwright (Java)
docs.text: In Playwright, handling multiple windows or tabs is a common scenario in web automation.\ Playwright treats each new tab/window as a Page object.

docs.title: 🔹 Opening a New Window / Tab
docs.text:
When a link opens a new window or tab, Playwright can listen for it.

// Example: Click link that opens new tab/window
Page newPage = page.waitForPopup(() -> {
    page.locator("a#openNewTab").click();
});

System.out.println("New Page Title: " + newPage.title());

docs.title: 🔹 Switching Window by Title
docs.text:
Suppose you want to switch to a tab/window with title "hellpword".

for (Page p : page.context().pages()) {
    if (p.title().equalsIgnoreCase("hellpword")) {
        System.out.println("Switched to page with title: " + p.title());
        p.bringToFront();   // Make it active
        break;
    }
}

docs.title: 🔹 Switching by Index of Tab
docs.text:
Each window/tab is stored in a list using context.pages().\ You can switch by index position.

// Get all pages
List<Page> allPages = page.context().pages();

// Switch to second tab (index starts at 0)
Page secondTab = allPages.get(1);
secondTab.bringToFront();

System.out.println("Now on Tab: " + secondTab.title());

docs.title: 🔹 Switching Using Keyboard (Tab Key)
docs.text:
Playwright supports keyboard actions.\ If you want to simulate switching tabs using Ctrl + Tab, you can send key presses.

// Press CTRL + TAB to switch to next tab (browser level)
page.keyboard().press("Control+Tab");

// Or Shift+Control+Tab to move backwards
page.keyboard().press("Control+Shift+Tab");

⚠️ Note: Keyboard tab switching works only if the browser supports shortcut handling.\ Preferred way is using context().pages().

docs.title: 🔹 Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always wait for popup when new tab/window opens.\
  • Use bringToFront() to activate the desired tab.\
  • Prefer switching by title or index, keyboard shortcuts are less reliable.\
  • Clean up by closing unused tabs:\
for (Page p : page.context().pages()) {
    if (!p.title().equals("Main Page")) {
        p.close();
    }
}

✅ With these methods, you can reliably handle multiple windows/tabs in Playwright with Java.

docs.title: 8. Handling Frames & iFrames in Playwright (Java)
docs.text: Frames (<frame>) and iFrames (<iframe>) allow embedding another HTML document inside the main page. Playwright provides APIs to switch context into frames and interact with elements inside them.

docs.title: What is an iFrame?
docs.text:
• An <iframe> is an HTML tag that loads another HTML page inside the current page.
  • Each frame has its own DOM and context, isolated from the main document.
  • To interact with elements inside frames, you must switch to the correct frame.

docs.title: 1. Access All Frames
docs.text:
page.frames(); // returns List<Frame>
  • Retrieves all frames in the page, including main frame + nested frames.

docs.title: 2. Access Frame by Name / URL
docs.text:
Frame frameByName = page.frame("frameName");
Frame frameByUrl = page.frameByUrl(".*someFrameUrl.*");

docs.title: 3. Access Nested Frames by Index
docs.text:
List<Frame> frames = page.frames();
Frame firstFrame = frames.get(1);   // index 0 is always the main page

docs.title: 4. Locate Frame Element and Get Frame Object
docs.text:
Locator frameLocator = page.frameLocator("iframe[name='frame1']");
  • Useful for directly chaining locators into frame elements.

docs.title: 📌 Example Code (Java + Playwright)
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;

public class FramesExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();

            // Navigate to page with frames
            page.navigate("https://the-internet.herokuapp.com/nested_frames");

            // --- Get all frames ---
            for (Frame f : page.frames()) {
                System.out.println("Frame: " + f.name() + " | URL: " + f.url());
            }

            // --- Switch to top frame (by name) ---
            Frame topFrame = page.frame("frame-top");
            System.out.println("Inside Top Frame: " + topFrame.name());

            // --- Nested frame (by index) ---
            Frame nestedLeft = topFrame.childFrames().get(0);
            System.out.println("Inside Nested Left Frame: " + nestedLeft.name());

            // Example: get text inside nested frame
            String text = nestedLeft.locator("body").innerText();
            System.out.println("Nested Frame Text: " + text);

            // --- Access frame by locator ---
            Frame frameExample = page.frameLocator("iframe[name='mce_0_ifr']").frame();
            frameExample.locator("#tinymce").fill("Hello inside iframe!");

            browser.close();
        }
    }
}

docs.title: 🔑 Notes
docs.text:
• Main Page vs Frames:
  • page → represents the main document.

  • frame → represents an iframe’s DOM.

  • Indexing:

  • page.frames().get(0) → main page.

  • page.frames().get(1+) → child frames.

  • Frame Locator vs Frame Object:

  • page.frame("name") → switch to a frame by name/id/URL.

  • page.frameLocator("selector") → chain locators inside an iframe without switching.

  • Nested Frames:

  • Use .childFrames() recursively to drill down multiple levels.

  • Best Practice:

  • Prefer frameLocator() for simplicity when working with a single iframe.
  • Use frames() list traversal for nested or multiple frame hierarchies.

✅ With these techniques, you can reliably handle single, nested, and multiple frames in Playwright tests using Java.

docs.title: Java Playwright UI Testing Interview Questions & Answers
docs.text: This document contains 20+ real-time interview questions for Java Playwright UI Testing with in-depth explanations and example code snippets.

docs.title: 1. What is Playwright, and how is it different from Selenium?
docs.text:
Answer: Playwright is an open-source automation library developed by Microsoft for web UI testing. Unlike Selenium, it supports: - Multiple browsers (Chromium, Firefox, WebKit) with a single API. - Auto-waiting for elements. - Network interception and mocking. - Headless and headful execution.

import com.microsoft.playwright.*;

public class LaunchBrowser {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();
            page.navigate("https://example.com");
            System.out.println(page.title());
        }
    }
}

docs.title: 2. How do you launch a browser in Playwright with Java?
docs.text:
Playwright playwright = Playwright.create();
Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
Page page = browser.newPage();
page.navigate("https://example.com");

docs.title: 3. How does Playwright handle synchronization (auto-waiting)?
docs.text:
Answer: Playwright automatically waits for elements to be actionable before performing actions like click() or fill(). Unlike Selenium, explicit waits are less frequently needed.

page.click("button#submit"); // Playwright waits until the button is clickable

docs.title: 4. How do you select elements in Playwright?
docs.text:
Answer: Selectors can be: - CSS selectors - XPath - Text selectors

page.click("text=Login");
page.fill("#username", "admin");
page.fill("input[name='password']", "pass123");

docs.title: 5. How do you handle multiple browser contexts?
docs.text:
Answer: Contexts allow isolated sessions, similar to incognito windows.

BrowserContext context1 = browser.newContext();
Page page1 = context1.newPage();
page1.navigate("https://example1.com");

BrowserContext context2 = browser.newContext();
Page page2 = context2.newPage();
page2.navigate("https://example2.com");

docs.title: 6. How do you handle multiple pages/tabs?
docs.text:
Page newPage = page.waitForPopup(() -> page.click("a[target='_blank']"));
newPage.waitForLoadState();
System.out.println(newPage.title());

docs.title: 7. How do you handle alerts in Playwright?
docs.text:
page.onceDialog(dialog -> {
    System.out.println("Alert message: " + dialog.message());
    dialog.accept();
});
page.click("#trigger-alert");

docs.title: 8. How do you perform assertions in Playwright with Java?
docs.text:
Playwright provides Assertions.

import static com.microsoft.playwright.assertions.PlaywrightAssertions.assertThat;

assertThat(page.locator("h1")).hasText("Welcome");

docs.title: 9. How do you upload files in Playwright?
docs.text: page.setInputFiles("input[type='file']", Paths.get("C:/files/sample.txt"));

docs.title: 10. How do you download files in Playwright?
docs.text:
Download download = page.waitForDownload(() -> {
    page.click("a#downloadLink");
});
System.out.println("Downloaded file: " + download.path());

docs.title: 11. How do you handle frames in Playwright?
docs.text:
Frame frame = page.frameByName("frameName");
frame.fill("#inputField", "Hello");

docs.title: 12. How do you take screenshots in Playwright?
docs.text: page.screenshot(new Page.ScreenshotOptions().setPath(Paths.get("screenshot.png")));

docs.title: 13. How do you handle hover actions in Playwright?
docs.text: page.hover("button#menu");

docs.title: 14. How do you handle drag and drop in Playwright?
docs.text: page.dragAndDrop("#source", "#target");

docs.title: 15. How do you emulate devices in Playwright?
docs.text:
BrowserContext context = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
    .setViewportSize(375, 667)
    .setUserAgent("Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 13_5 like Mac OS X)"));
Page mobilePage = context.newPage();
mobilePage.navigate("https://example.com");

docs.title: 16. How do you intercept and modify network requests?
docs.text:
page.route("**/api/**", route -> {
    route.fulfill(new Route.FulfillOptions().setBody("{"status":"mocked"}"));
});
page.navigate("https://example.com/api/test");

docs.title: 17. How do you wait for specific network responses?
docs.text:
Response response = page.waitForResponse("**/api/data", () -> {
    page.click("#fetchData");
});
System.out.println(response.status());

docs.title: 18. How do you record a video of test execution?
docs.text:
BrowserContext context = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
    .setRecordVideoDir(Paths.get("videos/")));
Page videoPage = context.newPage();
videoPage.navigate("https://example.com");
context.close(); // saves video

docs.title: 19. How do you mock geolocation in Playwright?
docs.text:
BrowserContext context = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
    .setGeolocation(37.7749, -122.4194)
    .setPermissions(Arrays.asList("geolocation")));
Page page = context.newPage();
page.navigate("https://maps.google.com");

docs.title: 20. How do you run tests in parallel with Playwright + TestNG?
docs.text:
Answer: Each test can run in its own browser context.

import org.testng.annotations.Test;

public class ParallelTest {
    @Test
    public void test1() {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch();
            BrowserContext context = browser.newContext();
            Page page = context.newPage();
            page.navigate("https://example.com");
        }
    }
}

docs.title: 21. How do you integrate Playwright with CI/CD pipelines?
docs.text:
Answer: - Install Playwright browsers in the pipeline. - Run tests using Maven/Gradle. - Publish results.

Example GitHub Actions YAML:

name: Playwright Tests

on: [push]

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - name: Setup Java
        uses: actions/setup-java@v3
        with:
          java-version: '17'
      - name: Install Playwright
        run: mvn exec:java -Dexec.mainClass="com.microsoft.playwright.CLI" -Dexec.args="install"
      - name: Run Tests
        run: mvn test

docs.title: 22. How do you handle cookies in Playwright?
docs.text:
// Get cookies
System.out.println(context.cookies());

// Add cookies
context.addCookies(Arrays.asList(new BrowserContext.AddCookiesOptions()
    .setName("session_id")
    .setValue("12345")
    .setUrl("https://example.com")));

docs.title: 23. How do you handle authentication in Playwright?
docs.text:
BrowserContext context = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
    .setHttpCredentials("username", "password"));
Page page = context.newPage();
page.navigate("https://secure-site.com");

docs.title: 24. How do you handle shadow DOM elements?
docs.text: page.locator("css=custom-element >>> button").click();

docs.title: 25. How do you handle slow networks in Playwright?
docs.text:
BrowserContext context = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
    .setOffline(false));
context.setDefaultNavigationTimeout(10000); // 10 seconds

docs.title: 26. How do you use Playwright Trace Viewer?
docs.text:
BrowserContext context = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
    .setRecordHarPath(Paths.get("trace.zip")));
Page page = context.newPage();
page.navigate("https://example.com");
context.close(); // trace saved

docs.title: 27. How do you mock API responses in Playwright?
docs.text:
page.route("**/api/data", route -> {
    route.fulfill(new Route.FulfillOptions()
        .setStatus(200)
        .setContentType("application/json")
        .setBody("{"message":"Mocked Response"}"));
});

docs.title: 28. How do you retry failed tests in Playwright with Java?
docs.text:
Answer: Use TestNG retry analyzers or JUnit retry rules. Playwright itself retries only locator actions.

for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
    try {
        page.click("#submit");
        break;
    } catch (Exception e) {
        if (i == 2) throw e;
    }
}

docs.title: 29. How do you handle basic authentication popups?
docs.text:
BrowserContext context = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
    .setHttpCredentials("user", "pass"));
Page page = context.newPage();
page.navigate("https://auth-site.com");

docs.title: 30. How do you test responsive design with Playwright?
docs.text:
Page mobilePage = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
    .setViewportSize(375, 667)).newPage();
mobilePage.navigate("https://example.com");

docs.title: 31. How do you test web accessibility with Playwright?
docs.text:
Playwright integrates with axe-core for accessibility testing.

Object accessibilityTree = page.accessibility().snapshot();
System.out.println(accessibilityTree.toString());

docs.title: 32. How do you handle retries and flaky tests?
docs.text:
Answer: - Use retry in CI/CD pipelines. - Avoid Thread.sleep(), prefer auto-wait or waitForSelector. - Stabilize locators.

page.locator("button#login").click(new Locator.ClickOptions().setTrial(true));

docs.title: 33. How do you run Playwright tests in Docker?
docs.text:
• Create a Dockerfile with Java + Playwright installed.
  • Run tests inside container.
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/playwright/java:v1.49.0-jammy
COPY . /app
WORKDIR /app
RUN mvn test

docs.title: 34. How do you debug Playwright tests?
docs.text:
• Use setHeadless(false)
  • Use page.pause() to inspect manually.
page.pause(); // Opens Playwright Inspector

docs.title: 35. How do you handle rate-limiting in API calls during tests?
docs.text:
Answer: - Add delays using page.waitForTimeout(ms). - Use network interception to simulate rate limits.

page.waitForTimeout(2000); // wait for 2 seconds

docs.title: 36. How do you capture console logs in Playwright?
docs.text:
page.onConsoleMessage(msg -> System.out.println("Console: " + msg.text()));
page.navigate("https://example.com");

docs.title: 37. How do you capture network requests and responses?
docs.text:
page.onRequest(request -> System.out.println("Request: " + request.url()));
page.onResponse(response -> System.out.println("Response: " + response.url()));

docs.title: 38. How do you handle multiple downloads in Playwright?
docs.text:
Download download = page.waitForDownload(() -> {
    page.click("a.download-all");
});
System.out.println(download.path());

docs.title: 39. How do you assert element visibility?
docs.text:
import static com.microsoft.playwright.assertions.PlaywrightAssertions.assertThat;
assertThat(page.locator("#logo")).isVisible();

docs.title: 40. How do you run Playwright tests with Gradle?
docs.text:
plugins {
    id 'java'
}

repositories {
    mavenCentral()
}

dependencies {
    implementation 'com.microsoft.playwright:playwright:1.49.0'
    testImplementation 'org.testng:testng:7.9.0'
}

docs.title: 41. How do you test single-page applications (SPAs) with Playwright?
docs.text:
Answer: Use waitForLoadState("networkidle") to ensure all async calls are complete.

page.click("#loadData");
page.waitForLoadState(LoadState.NETWORKIDLE);

docs.title: 42. How do you manage test data in Playwright?
docs.text:
Answer: - Use external files (JSON/CSV). - Use environment variables.

String username = System.getenv("TEST_USER");
page.fill("#username", username);

docs.title: Playwright Locators – Complete Guide (Java)
docs.text: This guide covers all locator strategies in Playwright (Java) with examples, including ARIA roles and accessibility-based locators.

docs.title: 🔹 Example HTML
docs.text:
<input type="text" id="email" class="form-control" placeholder="Enter email" />

<button id="submitBtn" class="btn btn-primary" type="submit">Submit</button>

<span class="text">Title</span>

<a href="/home">Home</a>

docs.title: 1. By ID
docs.text:
page.locator("#email");
page.locator("#submitBtn");

docs.title: 2. By Class
docs.text:
page.locator(".form-control");
page.locator(".btn.btn-primary");

docs.title: 3. By Tag Name
docs.text:
page.locator("button");
page.locator("input");

docs.title: 4. By Text Content
docs.text:
page.getByText("Submit");
page.getByText("Home");

docs.title: 5. By Role (ARIA Accessibility)
docs.text:
ARIA roles are accessibility attributes in HTML that define the purpose of an element for screen readers. Playwright’s getByRole uses the accessibility tree.

page.getByRole(AriaRole.BUTTON, new Page.GetByRoleOptions().setName("Submit"));
page.getByRole(AriaRole.LINK, new Page.GetByRoleOptions().setName("Home"));
  • Use getByRole for buttons, links, headings, checkboxes, etc.
  • More stable than CSS/XPath since roles rarely change.
  • Filters elements by their accessible name (text or ARIA label).

Example of explicit role in HTML:

<div role="button" aria-label="Submit Form">Submit</div>

Rule of Thumb: Prefer getByRole if a semantic role exists; fallback to XPath/CSS otherwise.

docs.title: 6. By Placeholder
docs.text: page.getByPlaceholder("Enter email");

docs.title: 7. By Label
docs.text:
<label for="email">Email</label>
<input id="email" />

page.getByLabel("Email");

docs.title: 8. By Alt Text
docs.text:
<img src="logo.png" alt="Company Logo">

page.getByAltText("Company Logo");

docs.title: 9. By Title Attribute
docs.text:
<button title="Click to submit">Submit</button>

page.getByTitle("Click to submit");

docs.title: 10. By CSS Attribute Selector
docs.text:
page.locator("input[type='text']");
page.locator("button[type='submit']");
page.locator("a[href='/home']");

docs.title: 11. By XPath
docs.text:
page.locator("//button[text()='Submit']");
page.locator("//input[@id='email']");

docs.title: 🔹 Handling Multiple Matches
docs.text:
<ul>
  <li class="item">Apple</li>
  <li class="item">Banana</li>
  <li class="item">Cherry</li>
</ul>

Locator items = page.locator(".item");
int count = items.count();

items.nth(0);  // Apple
items.nth(1);  // Banana
items.nth(2);  // Cherry

for (int i = 0; i < count; i++) {
    System.out.println(items.nth(i).innerText());
}

Locator banana = page.locator(".item").filter(new Locator.FilterOptions().setHasText("Banana"));

page.locator(".item").first();
page.locator(".item").last();

docs.title: 🔹 Summary
docs.text:
• Use semantic locators (getByRole, getByLabel, getByPlaceholder) for stable and accessibility-compliant tests.
  • Use CSS/XPath only if necessary.
  • Manage multiple elements using .count(), .nth(), .first(), .last(), .filter().
  • ARIA roles ensure robust, readable, and accessible test selection.

docs.title: Playwright – Drag & Drop and Keyboard Interactions (Java)
Example HTML
docs.text:
<div id="source" draggable="true">Drag me</div>
<div id="target">Drop here</div>

docs.title: a) Simple Drag and Drop using dragTo()
docs.text:
Locator source = page.locator("#source");
Locator target = page.locator("#target");

source.dragTo(target);
  • Simulates dragging from source element to target element.
  • Handles mouse events automatically.
  • Auto-waits for elements to be visible.

docs.title: b) Drag and Drop Using Mouse Actions
docs.text:
page.mouse().move(100, 200);  // Move to source coordinates
page.mouse().down();           // Click and hold
page.mouse().move(300, 400);  // Move to target coordinates
page.mouse().up();             // Release
  • Useful if elements are custom draggable items not directly supported by dragTo().

docs.title: c) Iterating Multiple Draggable Items
docs.text:
Locator items = page.locator(".draggable");
int count = items.count();
for (int i = 0; i < count; i++) {
    items.nth(i).dragTo(page.locator("#target"));
}
  • Allows dragging multiple items to the target container.

docs.title: d) Tips
docs.text:
• Use dragTo() for standard HTML5 draggable elements.
  • Use mouse() actions for custom implementations.
  • Combine with assertions to verify drop success.

docs.title: a) Typing Text (fill and type)
docs.text:
page.locator("#searchBox").fill("Playwright");  // Instant fill
page.locator("#searchBox").type("Automation");  // Simulate typing character by character
  • fill() sets value instantly.
  • type() triggers keyboard events.

docs.title: b) Pressing Keys
docs.text:
page.locator("#searchBox").press("Enter");     // Press Enter key
page.locator("#searchBox").press("Tab");       // Move focus to next element
  • Equivalent to sendKeys(Keys.ENTER) in Selenium.
  • Triggers keypress events.

docs.title: c) Keyboard Shortcuts / Combination Keys
docs.text:
page.keyboard().press("Control+A");  // Select all text
page.keyboard().press("Control+C");  // Copy
page.keyboard().press("Control+V");  // Paste
  • Can simulate shortcuts for copy, paste, undo, etc.

docs.title: d) Using keyboard.type() for Raw Input
docs.text:
page.keyboard().type("Hello World");  // Types text anywhere the focus is active
  • Useful when no input locator is available but you need to send keys globally.

docs.title: e) Full Example Flow
docs.text:
// Focus search box
page.locator("#searchBox").click();

// Fill and submit
page.locator("#searchBox").fill("Playwright");
page.locator("#searchBox").press("Enter");

// Select all text and delete
page.keyboard().press("Control+A");
page.keyboard().press("Backspace");

docs.title: ✅ Tips
docs.text:
• Playwright auto-waits for elements to be visible before keyboard interactions.
  • Use .press() for single keys or shortcuts, .type() for simulating typing character by character.
  • Drag & Drop and Keyboard methods can be combined for complex flows (e.g., drag + keyboard shortcuts).

docs.title: a) Click
docs.text:
Locator button = page.locator("#submitBtn");
button.click();
  • Simulates a single left mouse click on the element.

docs.title: b) Double Click
docs.text:
Locator textBox = page.locator("#inputBox");
textBox.dblclick();
  • Selects text or activates default double-click behavior.

docs.title: c) Hover
docs.text:
Locator menu = page.locator("#menu");
menu.hover();
  • Moves mouse over the element (useful for dropdowns, tooltips).

docs.title: d) Move Mouse
docs.text:
page.mouse().move(200, 300);
  • Moves mouse pointer to specific screen coordinates.

docs.title: e) Mouse Down and Up
docs.text:
page.mouse().move(100, 200); // Move to element
page.mouse().down();         // Press and hold mouse button
page.mouse().up();           // Release mouse button
  • Useful for drag-and-drop or click-and-hold actions.

docs.title: f) Click at Coordinates
docs.text:
page.mouse().click(150, 250);
  • Clicks at absolute screen coordinates, bypassing locators.

docs.title: g) Right Click
docs.text:
Locator element = page.locator("#contextMenu");
element.click(new Locator.ClickOptions().setButton(MouseButton.RIGHT));
  • Opens context menus.

docs.title: a) Type Text
docs.text:
page.keyboard().type("Hello");
  • Types text wherever the focus is set.

docs.title: b) Press Enter
docs.text:
page.keyboard().press("Enter");
  • Simulates pressing Enter key.

docs.title: c) Key Down and Key Up
docs.text:
page.keyboard().down("Shift");   // Hold Shift
page.keyboard().up("Shift");     // Release Shift
  • Useful for combinations like Shift+Click.

docs.title: d) Sequential Typing
docs.text:
Locator field = page.locator("#username");
field.pressSequentially("Playwright");
  • Types text character by character into a field (human-like typing).

docs.title: 🌐 Playwright Java – Navigation Actions
docs.text: This document explains all navigation-related actions available in Java Playwright with examples.

docs.title: 1. page.navigate("https://example.com")
docs.text:
👉 Navigates the browser to the given URL. - Waits until the page is loaded (load event by default). - Supports additional options like timeout, waiting for specific load states, etc.

Example:

Page page = context.newPage();
page.navigate("https://example.com");

With options (wait until DOM content loaded):

page.navigate("https://example.com",
    new Page.NavigateOptions().setWaitUntil(LoadState.DOMCONTENTLOADED));

docs.title: 2. page.goBack()
docs.text:
👉 Simulates the browser back button. - Goes to the previous page in the history. - Returns a Response object if navigation is successful, or null if there’s no history.

Example:

page.navigate("https://example.com");
page.navigate("https://google.com");

// Go back to example.com
page.goBack();

docs.title: 3. page.goForward()
docs.text:
👉 Simulates the browser forward button. - Moves forward in the history if available. - Returns a Response object or null if no forward entry exists.

Example:

page.goBack();     // goes to example.com
page.goForward();  // goes to google.com again

docs.title: 4. page.reload()
docs.text:
👉 Reloads the current page. - Similar to pressing the refresh button. - By default waits for the load event, but you can customize wait states.

Example:

page.reload();

With options:

page.reload(new Page.ReloadOptions().setWaitUntil(LoadState.DOMCONTENTLOADED));

docs.title: 5. page.title()
docs.text:
👉 Gets the title of the current page (the <title> tag content). - Returns a String.

Example:

String title = page.title();
System.out.println("Page title is: " + title);

docs.title: 6. page.url()
docs.text:
👉 Returns the current page URL as a String.

Example:

System.out.println("Current URL: " + page.url());

docs.title: 7. page.content()
docs.text:
👉 Returns the full HTML content of the page as a String. - Useful for debugging, parsing, or verifying HTML.

Example:

String html = page.content();
System.out.println(html);

docs.title: 🔑 Quick Notes
docs.text:
• navigate, goBack, goForward, and reload return a Response object → you can check status codes, headers, etc.
  • title, url, and content return String values → handy for validations in tests.
  • All navigation methods can take optional parameters like timeout and waitUntil (load, domcontentloaded, networkidle).

docs.title: 1️⃣ Typing / Entering Text into Input Boxes
docs.text:
Selenium Equivalent:

driver.findElement(By.id("searchBox")).sendKeys("Playwright");

docs.title: a) Using fill()
docs.text:
page.locator("#searchBox").fill("Playwright");
  • What it does: Clears any existing text and sets the new value.
  • Auto-waiting: Waits until the element is visible and enabled.
  • Best for: Setting values directly in forms.

docs.title: b) Using type()
docs.text:
page.locator("#searchBox").type("Playwright");
  • What it does: Types character by character, simulating real user typing.
  • Difference from fill():
  • fill() instantly sets the value.
  • type() simulates typing and triggers keyboard events.
  • Best for: Autocomplete, search boxes, or typing behavior testing.

docs.title: c) Pressing Keys
docs.text:
page.locator("#searchBox").fill("Playwright");
page.locator("#searchBox").press("Enter");
  • Equivalent to: sendKeys(Keys.ENTER) in Selenium.
  • Use case: Submitting forms via keyboard.

docs.title: d) Example Full Search Box Flow
docs.text:
page.locator("#searchBox").fill("Playwright");  // Type text instantly
page.locator("#searchBox").press("Enter");      // Submit by Enter key

docs.title: Difference Between fill() and type()
docs.text: Feature fill() type() Action Sets value instantly Types character by character Auto-clear Yes, clears existing text No, appends to existing text unless cleared manually Speed Fast Slower, simulates typing Events triggered Minimal Triggers keypress, input events Best for Form filling Autocomplete, typing simulation, keyboard events

docs.title: 2️⃣ Clicking on Buttons
docs.text:
Selenium Equivalent:

driver.findElement(By.id("submitBtn")).click();

docs.title: a) Simple Click
docs.text:
page.locator("#submitBtn").click();
  • Waits automatically for the button to be visible and enabled.
  • No need for Thread.sleep() or explicit waits.

docs.title: b) Click by Text
docs.text:
page.getByText("Submit").click();
  • Finds element by visible text.
  • Useful if ID or class is not available.

docs.title: c) Click by Role (ARIA)
docs.text:
page.getByRole(AriaRole.BUTTON, new Page.GetByRoleOptions().setName("Submit")).click();
  • Uses accessibility info (semantic role).
  • Very stable; less likely to break if HTML changes.
  • Recommended for modern accessible web apps.

docs.title: Java Playwright – Screenshots & Videos Examples
docs.text: This guide explains how to handle Screenshots and Videos in Java Playwright with practical code examples.

docs.title: ✅ Full Page Screenshot
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;
import java.nio.file.Paths;

public class FullPageScreenshot {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();

            page.navigate("https://example.com");

            // Capture full page screenshot
            page.screenshot(new Page.ScreenshotOptions()
                .setPath(Paths.get("C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Desktop\\fullpage.png"))
                .setFullPage(true));

            System.out.println("✅ Full page screenshot captured");
        }
    }
}

docs.title: ✅ Element Screenshot
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;
import java.nio.file.Paths;

public class ElementScreenshot {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();

            page.navigate("https://example.com");

            // Take screenshot of a specific element
            Locator heading = page.locator("h1");
            heading.screenshot(new Locator.ScreenshotOptions()
                .setPath(Paths.get("C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Desktop\\element.png")));

            System.out.println("✅ Element screenshot captured");
        }
    }
}

docs.title: ✅ Screenshot After Assertion
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;
import java.nio.file.Paths;

public class ScreenshotWithAssertion {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));
            Page page = browser.newPage();

            page.navigate("https://example.com");

            // Assertion
            String title = page.title();
            assert title.contains("Example");

            // Capture screenshot after validation
            page.screenshot(new Page.ScreenshotOptions()
                .setPath(Paths.get("C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Desktop\\assertion.png")));

            System.out.println("✅ Screenshot captured after assertion");
        }
    }
}

docs.title: ✅ Record Video for a Single Page
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;
import java.nio.file.Paths;

public class RecordVideoExample {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch(new BrowserType.LaunchOptions().setHeadless(false));

            // Enable video recording when creating context
            BrowserContext context = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
                .setRecordVideoDir(Paths.get("C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Desktop\\videos"))
                .setRecordVideoSize(1280, 720));

            Page page = context.newPage();
            page.navigate("https://example.com");
            page.click("a"); // some action

            // Close context to ensure video is saved
            context.close();

            System.out.println("✅ Video recorded and saved");
        }
    }
}

docs.title: ✅ Record Video for Each Test (Dynamic Naming)
docs.text:
import com.microsoft.playwright.*;
import java.nio.file.Paths;

public class RecordVideoDynamicName {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try (Playwright playwright = Playwright.create()) {
            Browser browser = playwright.chromium().launch();

            // Set folder where videos will be stored
            BrowserContext context = browser.newContext(new Browser.NewContextOptions()
                .setRecordVideoDir(Paths.get("C:\\Users\\Sandesh\\Desktop\\videos"))
                .setRecordVideoSize(1920, 1080));

            Page page = context.newPage();
            page.navigate("https://example.com");

            // Perform some actions
            page.click("a");

            // Retrieve video path after context closes
            context.close();

            for (Page p : context.pages()) {
                System.out.println("Video Path: " + p.video().path());
            }
        }
    }
}

docs.title: 📌 Key Notes
docs.text:
• Screenshots:
  • Use page.screenshot() for full page.
  • Use locator.screenshot() for specific elements.

  • Can be combined with assertions for debugging.

  • Videos:

  • Videos are recorded at the context level (not page level).
  • Use setRecordVideoDir() to specify folder for saving videos.
  • Close the context (context.close()) to ensure videos are written to disk.
  • Use p.video().path() to get the file path of the recorded video.

✅ This covers Full Page Screenshots, Element Screenshots, Assertion-based Screenshots, and Video Recording Scenarios in Java Playwright.
